article.description: Alabama rolled defending champ Syracuse to advance to the first Elite Eight in school history.
article.headline: Davis powers Tide past Syracuse

images.name: Warrick Hakim 040325 195x262
images.caption: For the 12 straight year, there won't be a back-to-back national champion, as Hakim Warrick and Gerry McNamara tasted NCAA defeat this year.

inlines.body:
Dick Vitale's Tourney Take
Wow, at this time of the year Alabama fans usually are concerned only with spring football. Not this year, baby! Coach Mark Gottfried has done a sensational job, and this is a sweet win since the Crimson Tide lost earlier this season to Big East opponents Pittsburgh and Providence. But the third time was the charm for Alabama. It was Soph's Night Out for the Tide. Forward Kennedy Winston dominated in the first half, and forward Chuck Davis came up big in the second half. Davis, who averages 11 points per game, scored 19 vs. Syracuse. Alabama's ability to hit big 3-pointers was a key to the victory (9-of-22 to 5-of-14 for the 'Cuse). Against Syracuse's 2-3 zone, it was so important to hit the 3-pointer, and Alabama did so to the tune of 40.9 percent. So Alabama is in the Elite Eight for the first time ever. Can the Tide score the upset against Connecticut? We'll find out Saturday.
More on Thursday's Games

article.story: SYRACUSE, N.Y. (AP) -- Hakim Warrick had 19 points and 11 rebounds and Josh Pace and Demetris Nichols each scored 17 points to lead Syracuse to a 91-59 exhibition victory over Division II St. Rose on Monday night. It was the second and final exhibition for the Orange, who beat Division II Le Moyne 101-46 last week. Adam McGuire led St. Rose with 13 points. Orange freshman Dayshawn Wright was 4-for-5 from the field for 11 points. Gerry McNamara scored only three points and had six assists in 22 minutes. Syracuse had a 44-24 halftime lead and led by as many as 37 points in the second half. The Orange open their season on Thursday night against Northern Colorado in the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic.
